revisions.rev:
{{Infobox Website |name = FactCheck |logo = |screenshot = |caption = |url = [http://www.factcheck.org FactCheck.org] |alexa = |commercial = no |type = |language = English |registration = |owner = |author = |launch date = |current status = |revenue = |slogan = }} '''FactCheck.org''' is a [[non-partisan]],{{cite news |author=Conkey, Christopher |date=2004-01-29 |title=Hitting the campaign trail via your PC; Our picks for five web sites that cut through the bluster |work=The Wall Street Journal |page=D1 |accessdate=2009-03-18}}
www.factcheck.org - Brooks Jackson, a former Cable News Network and Wall Street Journal reporter, debunks misleading claims, false attacks and subtle associations that litter the campaign trail on a Web site housed at the University of Pennsylvania's Annenberg Public Policy Center. It strives to reinforce the late New York Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan's conviction: "Everyone is entitled to their own opinion, but not their own facts." The site is thoroughly apolitical: Anyone who plays with the facts gets skewered. And Mr. Jackson keeps harping on things that offend him until they subside.
 nonprofit{{cite news |author=Hartlaub, Peter |date=2004-10-24 |title=Web sites help gauge the veracity of claims; Online resources check ads, rumors |work=San Francisco Chronicle |page=A1 |url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/chronicle/archive/2004/10/24/MNFACTS.DTL |accessdate=2009-03-18}} [[website]] that describes itself as a {{"'}}consumer advocate' for voters that aims to reduce the level of deception and confusion in [[Politics of the United States|U.S. politics]]."{{cite web|url=http://www.factcheck.org/about/ |title=About |publisher=FactCheck.org |date= |accessdate=2009-06-07}} It is a project of the [[Annenberg Public Policy Center]] of the [[Annenberg School for Communication at the University of Pennsylvania|Annenberg School for Communication]] at the [[University of Pennsylvania]], and is funded primarily by the [[Annenberg Foundation]]. FactCheck has won three Webby Awards in the Politics category, in 2008, 2010 and 2011.http://www.webbyawards.com/webbys/current.php?season=15 Most of its content consists of rebuttals to what it considers inaccurate, misleading, or false claims by politicians. FactCheck has also targeted misleading claims from various partisan groups. Besides maintaining a website, FactCheck.org distributes audio stories by [[podcast]][http://www.factcheck.org/feed/podcast/ FactCheck.org Radio]{{Dead link|date=April 2011}} and [[iTunes]] Radio.[http://wordpress.asc.upenn.edu/category/factcheck-radio/feed/]{{Dead link|date=April 2011}} ==Topic in the 2004 Vice-presidential debate== FactCheck.org became a focus of political commentary following the [[U.S. presidential election debates, 2004|2004 vice-presidential debate]] between [[Dick Cheney]] and [[John Edwards]]. Cheney cited the website, claiming that the independent site defended his actions while CEO of [[Halliburton]]. Cheney's claim is disputed by FactCheck.org as wrong, saying that "Edwards was mostly right" when talking about "Cheney's responsibility for earlier Halliburton troubles".{{cite web | url = http://www.factcheck.org/cheney_edwards_mangle_facts.html | title = Cheney & Edwards Mangle Facts | accessdate = 2010-01-10 | date = 2004-10-06 | publisher = Factcheck.org}} Cheney's reference created some controversy because he incorrectly cited the web site's address as "FactCheck.''com''." At the time of the debate, factcheck.com was controlled by [[Frank Schilling|Frank Schilling's]] company Name Administration Inc., who quickly redirected the address to point to an anti-Bush website owned by Bush critic [[George Soros]].{{cite news|last=Milbank|first=Dana|url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A12901-2004Oct6.html|publisher=Washington Post|date=2004-10-07|page=A08|title=Urging Fact-Checking, Cheney Got Site Wrong}} ==Spin-offs and other fact-checkers== * FactCheckEd.org:{{cite web|url=http://www.FactCheckEd.org |title=FactCheckED.org |publisher=FactCheckED.org |date=2008-12-11 |accessdate=2009-06-07}} An educational resource for high school teachers and students. Sister site to FactCheck.org and a project of the Annenberg Public Policy Center of the University of Pennsylvania.{{cite web|url=http://www.factchecked.org/AboutUs.aspx |title=About Us |publisher=FactCheckED.org |date= |accessdate=2009-06-07}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}} Created September 2005 * [[PolitiFact.com]]:{{cite web|url=http://www.PolitiFact.com |title=St. Petersburg Times Online |publisher=Politifact.com |date= |accessdate=2009-06-07}} A service of the ''[[St. Petersburg Times]]'' - Created August 2007, uses the "Truth-o-Meter" to rank the amount of truth in public persons' statements. 2009 [[Pulitzer Prize]] Winner. * WashingtonPost.com/factchecker:{{cite news|url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/factchecker |title=Fact Checker |publisher=Washingtonpost.com |date= |accessdate=2009-06-07}} A project of ''[[The Washington Post]]'', known for grading politicians on the factual accuracy of their statements with one to four "Pinocchios."{{cite news|url=http://blog.washingtonpost.com/fact-checker/2007/09/about_the_fact_checker.html |title=About the Fact Checker - Fact Checker |publisher=Blog.washingtonpost.com |date= |accessdate=2009-06-07}} Created September 2007 by Post diplomatic writer [[Michael Dobbs (US author)|Michael Dobbs]] specifically for the 2008 presidential campaign.{{cite news|url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m0EIN/is_2007_Sept_19/ai_n27378605 |title=washingtonpost.com Launches "FactChecker" |publisher=Findarticles.com |date= |accessdate=2009-06-07 | year=2007}} Shutdown Nov 4, 2008.{{cite news|url=http://voices.washingtonpost.com/fact-checker/ |title=Fact Checker |publisher=Voices.washingtonpost.com |date= |accessdate=2009-06-07}} Relaunched with a broader focus on Jan. 11, 2011 with veteran Washington Post diplomatic correspondent [[Glenn Kessler (journalist)|Glenn Kessler]] at the helm. {{cite news|url=http://voices.washingtonpost.com/fact-checker/2011/01/welcome_to_the_new_fact_checke.html | work=The Washington Post | title=Welcome to the new Fact Checker}} * Bama Fact Check:{{cite web|url=http://www.bamafactcheck.com |title=Bama Fact Check |publisher=www.bamafactcheck.com |date=2010-08-31 |accessdate=2010-11-07}} An Alabama-based, statewide partnership of newsgathering organizations which checks factual claims by politicians and public figures in Alabama. Partners in the project include ''[[The Anniston Star]]'', ''[[The Decatur Daily]]'', ''[[The Dothan Eagle]]'', ''[[The Florence TimesDaily]]'', ''[[The Opelika-Auburn News]]'', ''[[The Tuscaloosa News]]'' and [[WVTM-TV]] in Birmingham. ==See also== * [[Snopes.com]] * ''[[The Straight Dope]]'' * ''[[The Skeptic's Dictionary]]'' * ''[[MythBusters]]'' * [[Fact checker]] * [[List of common misconceptions]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{Official website|http://www.factcheck.org}} [[Category:American political websites]] [[Category:University of Pennsylvania]]
